prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The overall equities of any given fact situation will, although not always readily acknowledged, be significant in determining the restrictions placed by a court upon a departed employee.

Where an employer can demonstrate that information has economic value and was produced through the expenditure of effort and resources, the courts are far more likely to restrain a former employee from making use of the information.

The circumstances of the specific employment relationship will determine how the employee's duties—whether general, fiduciary, or resulting from a restrictive covenant—are to be viewed. A key consideration will be the circumstances under which the employment relationship came to an end, both in relation to the employee's actions prior to and at departure, and the employer's treatment of the employee. Where an employee breaches the general duty of good faith through a conflict of interest, particularly if he or she is subject to a restrictive covenant or occupied a fiduciary position, the court will be far more likely to protect the employer's information.[1] However, where the employee has been dismissed unfairly terminated or provided with inadequate notice of termination, the opposite may be true.[2]
Certain activities committed by the employee prior to departure will improve the employer's chances of protecting its information. These activities include:
contacting the employer's customers, suppliers or employees with a view to competition;
taking information in documentary or other forms (such as computer disks);
misuse of company funds or resources (charges for the use of telephones, facsimiles, couriers, etc.); and
improper use of company property (vehicles, pagers, boardrooms, etc.).

However, if other legal prerequisites --- such as significant customer relationships, specific information worthy of protection, or a reasonable level of seniority --- are absent, a court may conclude that there should be no restraint placed on the former employee, even where the employee has breached some duty.[3]

Generally, where no fiduciary or restrictive covenant duties are involved, the courts will not stop an employee from joining a competitor. The situation may be different where there was a breach of the duty of good faith prior to departure. To date, the Canadian courts have not been willing to accept the U.S. doctrine of “inevitable disclosure”, namely that the employee by the mere fact of re-employment will use and disclose confidential business information.[4]

Other factors considered by the courts in the context of employment law include the general economic situation, market conditions,[5] the availability of others with similar skills,[6] the nature of the business and the practice of the trade.[7]
See, for example, Reed Shaw Osler Ltd. v. Wilson (1981), 35 A.R. 451, 17 Alta. L.R. (2d) 81 (C.A.).

See for example Restauronics Services Ltd. v. Forster (2001), 13 C.P.R. (4th) 1 at paras. 60 and 69 (B.C.S.C.), appeal allowed in part 239 D.L.R. (4th) 98, [2004] 5 W.W.R. 233 (C.A.). See also, Canned Heat Marketing Inc. v. CFM International Inc. (1998), 81 A.C.W.S. (3d) 811, [1998] B.C.J. No. 1917 (QL) (S.C.), where the court made it clear that the parties can end the duty through agreement. See also Jostens Canada Ltd. v. Zbieranek (1992), 42 C.C.E.L. 264, 42 C.P.R. (3d) 519 (Ont. Ct. (Gen. Div.)).

See, for example, Sun Drilling Products Corp. v. Garrett (1999), 245 A.R. 370, 37 C.P.C. (4th) 356 (Q.B.), where the defendant employee, prior to the end of his employment, took all of his employer's assets and property, deleted all computer files related to Canadian operations, attempted to appropriate the company's lease for his own use, and advised suppliers and employees that the company was no longer in business. See Turbo Resources Ltd. v. Gibson (1987), 60 Sask. R. 221, 15 C.I.P.R. 207 (C.A.).

As to the inevitable disclosure doctrine, see Eastman Kodak Co. v. Powers Film Prods., 189 A.D. 556, 561; 179 N.Y.S. 325, 340 (4th Dept. 1919); Pepsico v. Redmond, 54 F. 3d 1262 (7th Cir. 1995); Lumex Inc. v. Highsmith, 919 F. Supp. 624 (E.D.N.Y. 1996); and Doubleclick Inc. v. Henderson, 1997 WL 731413, No. 116914/97 (N.Y. Co. Ct. Nov. 5, 1997). For a good analysis of this topic, see C. Heer, “Employees and Trade Secrets: How the Concept of Inevitable Disclosure May Fit into Canadian Law” (2006), 19 I.P.J. 323.

For example, in Thomas Marshall (Exporters) Ltd. v. Guinle, [1978] 3 W.L.R. 116 (Ch.), the court, albeit in obiter, specifically included the nature of an industry as one of the four elements which can be used to identify confidential information. It stated that the information must be considered in light of the practice of the particular industry. See also Drake International Ltd. v. Miller (1975), 61 D.L.R. (3d) 420 at pp. 424-9, 9 O.R. (2d) 652 (H.C.J.); Routh v. Jones, [1947] 1 All E.R. 758 (C.A.), at p. 761; GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth, 2012 CarswellOnt 2539, 2012 ONCA 134.
